reviewText: I'm so glad this is out on DVD. The picture and sound are REALLY good. A classic show that belongs in any Siouxsie & the Banhees' fan archive.

reviewText: For those of you wondering why Amazon does not carry this title, or why the DVD is region-ambiguous: The DVD listed is IMPORT ONLY!  The title will be released state-side on June 20th, 2006 (thanks Tower Records for the info).
Title: N/A

reviewText: Absolutely worth the wait, and every cent I paid for it. This concert is among the most important of the post-punk era, and highlights the Banshees at an early peak. Sioux sings like her life depends on it, completely erasing the memories of the painfully off-key performances from the 7 Year Itch DVD. Here she is by turns menacing, alluring and mystifying; without a doubt one of the very  best performers of our generation. The band, although terribly static,( Robert Smith rarely lifts his eyes from the fret board of his guitar ) is a powerhouse. Budgie's drumming in particular is a wonderful revelation, thanks to the new 5.1 Surround mix. The extras are a fascinating look inside the Banshees' Wonderland. Filmed for the BBC in 1983 and only now available to US audiences, this is part tea-party ( a total hoot - catch the band members in Alice in Wonderland drag, as well as producer Mike Hedges as the Queen of Hearts ) part poetry slam, part music video. And if nothing else it gives proof of the rabid acid intake of certain band members at the time. Nocturne is a must-have for Banshees fans new and old and is a long time coming. One final note about the DVD region mystery. My copy has a sticker on it stating it was manufactured in Germany and I've had no problems playing it on my computer, in my home theater system nor in my  portable DVD player.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A superbly-shot show at The Royal Albert Hall in 1983, comprising material from their 5 first records. No songs from Hyena, though, maybe due to the poor reception that album had back then ( I personally still don't like it ). The tracklist is far from ideal IMHO but gets the job done and the end result is a majestic 60' show before a venue filled to capacity (I'd never seen so many punks together-not even at a punk show !! ).The takes are from two different nights but the editing is seamless so you barely notice anything but wardrobe changes (Siouxsie darling, please shave those armpits !! LOL !! ). Personally, I could have used any of the other guitarrists the band had but Robert Smith was an integrant at the time ; nothing personal, but I prefer more aggro with my guitarwork and Smith's is softer if excellent and gets the job done with dignity.The picture is a direct but very good vhs transfer, 4:3, and plagued with some video artifacts stemming from the fact that this was videotaped instead of filmed.The sound, on the other hand, has been remixed in 2.0 , 5.1 AND DTS !! The lower end (bass and drums) is weak; it required some cranking from my big sub to make its presence felt. The rest of the spectrum is crystal clear and fantastically mixed. The guitar is spot-on panned in stereo and Siouxsie's voice never sounded better.The bonus tracks are 2 songs from TV show Old Grey Whistle Test (fair sound), the GORGEOUS Dear Prudence vid and the Play At Home DIY film by the band including music and clips by parallel bands The Creatures and The Glove (one clip per band which titles are nowhere to be found.If you're a fan of the band, you must own this beauty.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Plenty of reviews have mentioned the presence of Robert "Fat Bob" Smith, the different track listing from the live LP/CD, and Siouxsie's need of yard work under her arms.But not enough has been made of the "Play At Home" BBC special. That is just amazing to watch and makes me wish more bands had done wacky TV specials like that. It would have been amazing to show some of the "gother than thou" folks in nine inch nails that video a couple decades ago.This video delivers both the main course in the concert, great bonus videos as a side, and the sinfully over the top dessert with the "Play At Home" special. And that's something very few home videos (especially from that era) manage to do.
summary: "Play At Home" alone is worth the purchase!
Title: N/A
